data.title: Chickens, foxes and snakes
data.statement:
Foxes kill chickens, chickens kill snakes, snakes kill foxes.

Chickens always start.

Every turn :
- If there is a chicken left, one snake dies
- Then, if there is a snake left, one fox dies
- Then, if there is a fox left, one chicken dies

Only one animal is killed at a time.
The chickens kill one snake, then the snakes kill one fox, etc.

For example, with 1 chicken, 2 snakes and 3 foxes that would do:
1 2 3
1 1 3 // chickens kill one snake
1 1 2 // snakes kill one fox
0 1 2 // foxes kill one chicken
0 1 2 // no chicken left, therefore no snake dies
0 1 1 // snakes kill one fox
0 1 1 // no chicken to kill, therefore the foxes kill nothing
0 1 0 // snakes kill one fox => one snake left

You are given how many animals are there at start.
Tell which animals will eventually survive and how many of them will be left.

A brute-force approach should be able to handle most cases but only optimised algorithms can handle the cases involving large numbers.
data.constraints:
0 < [[N]] < 999999999

 [[NAME]] is one of the three animals: {{CHICKENS}}, {{FOXES}} and {{SNAKES}}.
data.stubGenerator:
loop 3 read line:string(128)
write CHICKENS SNAKES FOXES
data.inputDescription: <<{{3}} lines>> A string [[NAME]] and an integer [[N]] separated by a space, for the name and quantity of each animal
data.outputDescription: <<1 line>> A string [[NAME]] and an integer [[N]] separated by a space, for which animal is not extinct and how many are left

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Foxes kill chickens, chickens kill snakes, snakes kill foxes.

Chickens always start.

Every turn :
- If there is a chicken left, one snake dies
- Then, if there is a snake left, one fox dies
- Then, if there is a fox left, one chicken dies

Only one animal is killed at a time.
The chickens kill one snake, then the snakes kill one fox, etc.

For example, with 1 chicken, 2 snakes and 3 foxes that would do:
1 2 3
1 1 3 // chickens kill one snake
1 1 2 // snakes kill one fox
0 1 2 // foxes kill one chicken
0 1 2 // no chicken left, therefore no snake dies
0 1 1 // snakes kill one fox
0 1 1 // no chicken to kill, therefore the foxes kill nothing
0 1 0 // snakes kill one fox => one snake left

You are given how many animals are there at start.
Tell which animals will eventually survive and how many of them will be left.

A brute-force approach should be able to handle most cases but only optimised algorithms can handle the cases involving large numbers.
Input
3 lines A string NAME and an integer N separated by a space, for the name and quantity of each animal
Output
1 line A string NAME and an integer N separated by a space, for which animal is not extinct and how many are left
Constraints
0 < N < 999999999

NAME is one of the three animals: CHICKENS, FOXES and SNAKES.
Example
Input
CHICKENS 5
SNAKES 3
FOXES 4
Output
FOXES 2
